were hanging down equally to the left [and] the right, in the blue hairdress of your hair are comparable to that: the left [and] right
... together with [your] Buddha rank face. When the blue, red, white, and golden (rays) from your hair, lips, teeth [and]
(eyes) mix together, they stand surrounding [your] whole Buddha rank body like the sun god. I honour that (face) of yours.
... gathered shoulders, like a divine golden throne flat, broad and wide [is] your chest. Of a golden elephant ...

wsāṣy-ople〈ṃ〉 tsākkiñ: Sieg and Siegling read oplen sākkiñ^ä\ (209), but compare this form in their grammar to b1 tsākkiñ (101). Here tsākkiñ is read, but it should be noted that the anusvāra that this reading requires has to be added against the manuscript. (ople(ṃ) sākkiñ in 89b is a typographical error.) As for the meaning, the context in my view suggests that it should be a part of a lotus, for instance "petals". I.e. the hair of the Buddha is as beautiful as lotus flowers hanging down on both sides.
kusraṃ: as pointed out by 251, this form can only be a loc.sg., not a nom.du. (pace 157–158). For the meaning, he suggests 'toison', i.e. 'mop' instead of Carling's 'braid'.

(aśnäṣ ¦ swāñcenāñ): aśnäṣ 'from the eyes' as the fourth term is suggested by e.g. VAV10.1–20, which describe the eyes, the lips and the teeth of the Buddha (cf. 269; the next strophes there concern body hair rather than hair of the head). swāñcenāñ 'rays' is suggested by the colours mentioned before. With these restorations, the metre fits.

Text notes

1 wsāṣy-ople〈ṃ〉 tsākkiñ: Sieg and Siegling read oplen sākkiñ^ä\ ([[TochSprR(A)]]: 209), but compare this form in their grammar to [[A 192]] b1 tsākkiñ ([[TG]]: 101). Here tsākkiñ is read, but it should be noted that the anusvāra that this reading requires has to be added against the manuscript. (ople(ṃ) sākkiñ in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 89b is a typographical error.) As for the meaning, the context in my view suggests that it should be a part of a lotus, for instance "petals". I.e. the hair of the Buddha is as beautiful as lotus flowers hanging down on both sides.
2 kusraṃ: as pointed out by [[Itkin 2011]]: 251, this form can only be a loc.sg., not a nom.du. (pace [[Carling, DThTA]]: 157–158). For the meaning, he suggests 'toison', i.e. 'mop' instead of Carling's 'braid'.
4 (aśnäṣ ¦ swāñcenāñ): aśnäṣ 'from the eyes' as the fourth term is suggested by e.g. VAV10.1–20, which describe the eyes, the lips and the teeth of the Buddha (cf. [[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 269; the next strophes there concern body hair rather than hair of the head). swāñcenāñ 'rays' is suggested by the colours mentioned before. With these restorations, the metre fits.
